subj-group.subject: Clinical Images in Nephrology and Dialysis

title-group.article-title: An ESKD Patient with Unusual Findings on Abdominal Imaging

contrib-group.aff: Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence: Dr. Remy Fadel, email: remyfadel18@gmail.com

sec.title: Case Description
sec.p: A 69-year-old man with a history of ESKD undergoing intermittent hemodialysis and recent total knee arthroplasty presented to the emergency department with new-onset nausea, vomiting, and decreased appetite. A computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis scout film revealed hyperattenuated foci in the colon, presumed to be metallic objects (Figure 1). The patient was having daily soft bowel movements and passing flatus. He denied ingesting anything unusual, and his abdominal examination was unremarkable.

caption.p: CT scan scout film image demonstrates rounded, hyperattenuating intraluminal foci throughout the colon. CT, computed tomography.

sec.p: The general surgery team opted for a watchful management approach, as the metallic objects in the colon had not caused perforation or erosion and were likely to pass without any intervention. Further discussion with the patient revealed that he has been swallowing his iron-based phosphate binders, sucroferric oxyhydroxide, whole instead of chewing them. The coin-shaped abnormalities observed on imaging matched the size and shape of these binders, as confirmed by radiology, and later observed in the patient's stools. With a phosphorus level of 3.6 mg/dl on admission, the patient's phosphate binders were temporarily discontinued. As a result, his symptoms improved, and a follow-up kidney-ureter-bladder X-ray confirmed the evacuation of foreign objects a few days into the admission.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Ingestion of foreign bodies is a common clinical occurrence, which have the potential for life-threatening complications. It is crucial to differentiate this condition from the ingestion of radio-opaque medications that may share similar radiographic appearances.

Radiologists are faced with challenges of distinguishing between the ingestion of radio-opaque pills, foreign bodies, and calcified structures, which has prompted the development of the CHIPS mnemonic. CHIPS stands for Chloral hydrate, Heavy metals, Iron, Phenothiazines, and Slow release (enteric-coated preparations). Savitt et al.1 prospectively investigated 312 pills to assess in vivo radiodensity using cadavers. The study revealed that iron and calcium-based compositions were the most radio-opaque. However, there were significant variations in radiodensity on the basis of the preparation. For instance, ferric sulfate demonstrated greater opacity than ferric gluconate preparations.

Sucroferric oxyhydroxide is a chewable iron-based phosphate binder with an active moiety of polynuclear iron (III)-oxyhydroxide, which is insoluble with very little iron absorption.2 When ingested without chewing, these pills are radio-opaque with high Hounsfield units (up to 3000), potentially causing nonspecific gastrointestinal symptoms. Importantly, patients face no risk of systemic iron toxicity from these pills.

list-item.p: Medications that are radiopaque on imaging are described in the Chloral hydrate, Heavy metals, Iron, Phenothiazines, and Slow release acronym.
These include calcium carbonate, iodinated compounds, acetazolamide, busulfan, and potassium preparations.
It is imperative to differentiate these substances from other instances of foreign body ingestion.

ack.p: Informed consent was obtained from the patient.
